revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian | name = Kevin Nealon | image = Kevinnealon.jpg | caption = Nealon in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], 2006 | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1953|11|18}} | birth_place = [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], [[United States|U.S.]] | origin = [[Bridgeport]], [[Connecticut]] | othername = | medium = Stand-up, television, film | nationality = American | active = 1984–present | genre = [[Satire]], [[political satire]], [[news satire]], [[observational comedy]] | subject = [[Politics of the United States|American politics]], [[Culture of the United States|American culture]], current events, [[popular culture|pop culture]], [[mass media]], [[news media]], everyday life, [[marriage]] | spouse = Linda Dupree (1989–2002)
[[Susan Yeagley]] (2005–present; 1 child) | notable_work = [[Weekend Update]] anchor on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''
Gary Potter in ''[[Happy Gilmore]]''
Doug Wilson in ''[[Weeds (TV Series)|Weeds]]''
Glenn Martin in ''[[Glenn Martin, DDS]]''
Bruce in ''[[Daddy Day Care]]'' | domesticpartner = | website = }} '''Kevin Nealon''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|iː|l|ən}}; born November 18, 1953) is an American actor and comedian, best known as a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' from 1986 to 1995, acting in several of the [[Happy Madison]] films, for playing Doug Wilson on the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] series ''[[Weeds (TV series)|Weeds]]'', and providing the voice of the title character, Glenn Martin, on ''[[Glenn Martin, DDS]]''. ==Early life== Nealon was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], the son of Kathleen M. (née Kimball) and Emmett F. Nealon, an aircraft company executive.http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20000917-NEWS-309179979?cid=sitesearch A few months after he was born, the family moved to [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]].As told in his book, ''Yes, You're Pregnant, But What About Me?'' He is of Irish descent,https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TFzdL-3exz4&feature=youtu.be&t=264 and was raised Catholic.http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20100902-ENTERTAIN-9020322 He graduated from [[St. Joseph High School (Trumbull, Connecticut)|St. Joseph High School]] in [[Trumbull, Connecticut]], in 1971. Nealon graduated with a [[bachelor's degree]] in marketing from [[Sacred Heart University]] (and worked in a variety of part-time jobs while doing [[stand-up comedy]]).Loveline 1/26/2004 around the 42 minute mark Nealon then took some night courses at [[Fairfield University]], where he became the starting quarterback for the school's football team. ==Career== Nealon debuted on network television doing a stand-up routine for ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' in 1984. On the September 24, 1985 nighttime syndicated episode of ''[[Sale of the Century]]'', Nealon can be seen onstage congratulating his friend Tim Holleran on winning more than $150,000 in cash and prizes. In 1986, ''Saturday Night Live'' recruited his friend [[Dana Carvey]], and Carvey in turn recommended Nealon. Both joined the cast that year, and Nealon became a full-time performer in the 1987–1988 season, and remained for nine seasons. Nealon's ''SNL'' characters include [[Saturday Night Live characters appearing on Weekend Update#Mr. Subliminal|Mr. Subliminal]] (or Subliminal Message Man), Franz (of [[Hans and Franz]]) along with [[Dana Carvey]], Mr. No Depth Perception, the anchor of [[Weekend Update]] (where he ended each edition with "I'm Kevin Nealon, and that's news to me"), and many others. In 1991, he starred in the Christmas movie, ''[[All I Want for Christmas (film)|All I Want for Christmas]]''. More recently Nealon has appeared in the movies ''[[Happy Gilmore]]'', ''[[Anger Management (film)|Anger Management]]'', ''[[Little Nicky]]'', ''[[Daddy Day Care]]'', ''[[Good Boy!]]'' and ''[[Grandma's Boy (2006 film)|Grandma's Boy]]''. In fall 2005, he appeared in an episode of ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]'', where he played himself (Season 5, Episode 4). Nealon had a recurring television role on the 2002-06 CBS comedy ''[[Still Standing (TV series)|Still Standing]]'' playing Ted Halverson, the Millers' competitive and religious neighbor. He has also appeared as a patient in a mental institution on the first season of ''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]''. "Deja Vu" is an episode of ''[[The Outer Limits (1995 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]'' television show. It first aired on 9 July 1999, during the fifth season. Nealon played Dr. Mark Crest. Nealon also had an ongoing supporting role as Doug Wilson on the show ''[[Weeds (TV series)|Weeds]]'' on Showtime. In 1994, Nealon hosted the 13 part series ''Amazing America'' on the [[Discovery Channel]].{{cite book|title=The Complete Directory to Prime Time to Prime Time Network and Cable TV Shows, 1946-Present|year=2003|publisher=Ballantine Books|isbn=0-345-45542-8|pages=311}} In 2002, Nealon hosted ''[[The Conspiracy Zone]]'' on [[Spike (TV channel)|The New TNN]] for 26 episodes plus an unaired [[television pilot|pilot]]. Nealon appeared as a couples counselor on the sitcom, ''[[3rd Rock from the Sun]]''. He had a small [[cameo appearance]] in the 2008 film ''[[Get Smart (film)|Get Smart]]''. Nealon also hosted the ''World's Funniest Commercials'' on TBS. In a performance similar to Bob Saget, Nealon tells corny jokes in between each funny commercial. In 2008, a book authored by Nealon chronicling his experiences during his wife's pregnancy called ''Yes, You're Pregnant, But What About Me?'' was released. Nealon played Stuart Pearson in the adventure comedy ''[[Aliens in the Attic]]''. Shooting took place in [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]. Nealon currently portrays Captain Telstar in the Charter Spectrum commercials. He has a YouTube and Twitter interview show, Hiking With Kevin. ==Personal life== [[File:SusanYeagleyKevinNealonApr2011.jpg|thumb|right|Nealon with wife [[Susan Yeagley]] in April 2011]] Nealon married actress [[Susan Yeagley]] on September 3, 2005 in [[Bellagio (Italian region)|Bellagio]], [[Italy]]. Yeagley gave birth to their first child, son Gable Ness Nealon, on January 29, 2007 in [[Santa Monica, California]].{{cite web|accessdate=2008-05-22|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20010313,00.html|title=Kevin Nealon Welcomes First Child|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=2007-01-30}} Nealon played rugby for [[Connecticut Yankees RFC]].{{cite web|accessdate=2008-05-22|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/kevin-nealon/bio/160617|title=Kevin Nealon: Biography|work=[[TV Guide]]}} On February 22, 2006, Nealon{{cite web|accessdate=2008-05-22|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/22/opinion/22nealon.html?_r=1&oref=slogin|title=Don't Stop Bugging Me |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2006-02-22|author=Nealon, Kevin}} contributed a story to the ''[[New York Times]]'' about being [[wiretapped]] by [[Hollywood]] [[private investigator]] [[Anthony Pellicano]], who has been indicted on [[racketeering]] and conspiracy charges. It was also revealed in a separate court case on February 27, 2006, that investigators working for the [[Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus]] may also have targeted Nealon for wiretapping.{{cite web|accessdate=2008-05-22|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/27/AR2006022701436.html|title=Ringling Circus Hired Private Eye To Infiltrate PETA, Fairfax Jury Told|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=2006-02-28|author=Jackman, Tom}} He is a [[vegetarian]] because of concerns about [[animal cruelty]] and for health reasons.{{cite web|accessdate=2008-05-22 |url=http://www.goveg.com/f-kevin_nealon.asp |title=Weeds Star Kevin Nealon's Vegetarian Testimonial |publisher=Go Veg |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511210125/http://www.goveg.com/f-kevin_nealon.asp |archivedate=2008-05-11 |df= }} He is an avid golfer and [[poker]] player and also plays [[banjo]] and [[guitar]]. He also claims to be fluent in German, having lived in Germany for four years.{{YouTube|kKhqNWqos2w|"The Kevin Nealon Show : Chris D'Elia"}}. Retrieved July 7, 2012 ==Activism== Nealon and his former wife Linda Dupree (who played one of the mud wrestlers fighting [[John Candy]] in ''[[Stripes (film)|Stripes]]'') had been active in the [[animal rights]] movement, supporting the Amanda Foundation, [[Farm Sanctuary]], the Washington Wildlife Protection Association, The [[Ark Trust]]'s Genesis Awards, [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] and also Meat Out. In 2001, Nealon played on ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire (U.S. game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire]]'' for his charity. The final question he faced, worth $125,000, was about [[Barbie]] dolls. He used his Phone-A-Friend and 50:50, but he answered the question incorrectly, thus losing $32,000 of $64,000 he had, and ended up walking away with $32,000 for his charity. ==Filmography== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 90%;" |-style="background:#B0C4DE;" ! Bang!]]'' | Milkman | Episode: "Amber Tamblyn Wears a Leather Jacket & Black Booties" |- | rowspan="3"| 2016 | ''[[@midnight]]'' | Himself | Episode: Nikki Glaser, Jim Jeffries, Kevin Nealon |- | ''[[The Soul Man (2012 TV series)|The Soul Man]]'' | Ron Saxby | Episodes: "This Mud's for You", "No Bingo, No Peace" |- | ''[[Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping]]'' | Gary Sikes | |- | 2016–present | ''[[Man with a Plan (TV series)|Man with a Plan]]'' | Don Burns | Series regular |- |2018 |''[[Father of the Year (film)|Father of the Year]]'' | | |} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * {{official site|http://www.kevinnealon.com/}} * {{Twitter}} * {{IMDb name|5265}} * [http://www.revuemm.com/sights/comedy/item/687-kevin-nealon 2012 interview with Kevin Nealon]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071110001446/http://www.sfstandup.com/blog/2007/10/30/kevin-nealon-interview/ Interview from October 2007 on San Francisco comedy website] {{s-start}} {{s-media}} {{succession box | title=''[[Weekend Update]]'' anchor | before=[[Dennis Miller]] | after=[[Norm Macdonald]] | years=1991–1994}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nealon, Kevin}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American sketch comedians]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:American television writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from Bridgeport, Connecticut]] [[Category:Male television writers]] [[Category:Poker commentators]] [[Category:Sacred Heart Pioneers football players]] [[Category:Sacred Heart University alumni]] [[Category:Fairfield University alumni]]
